item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Qiu Xiaolong on His Novel ‘Shanghai Redemption’
item.description: In Qiu Xiaolong’s new novel, “Shanghai Redemption,” Inspector Chen Cao finds himself once again enmeshed in political struggles partly influenced by the real-life downfall of Bo Xilai, the party chief of Chongqing.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Indonesian Plane Carrying 54 Is Declared Missing in Papua
item.description: The commercial airliner was carrying 54 people when it vanished on Sunday amid bad weather in the eastern region of Papua, an official said.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Assisi Journal: In St. Francis’ Hometown, a New Kind of Pilgrim
item.description: New Age retreats that offer yoga, meditation and spa treatments are cropping up in Assisi, Italy, a spot popular with Catholic pilgrims for centuries.
item.dc:creator: NINA BURLEIGH
item.media:credit: Andrea Wyner for The New York Times
item.media:description: New Age retreats like the Ananda Center attract visitors with yoga classes and spa treatments.

item.title: Comeback Hopes Dim for Sri Lanka’s Ex-President Ahead of Parliamentary Elections
item.description: Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was voted out of office in January, is trying to become prime minister, but opponents are determined to bury his political hopes once and for all.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW
item.media:description: Election workers gathered on Sunday in Colombo, Sri Lanka, to prepare for the country’s parliamentary vote on Monday.

item.title: Comeback Hopes Dim for Sri Lanka’s Ex-President Ahead of Parliamentary Elections
item.description: Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was voted out of office in January, is trying to become prime minister, but opponents are determined to bury his political hopes once and for all.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW
item.media:description: The comeback attempt by former President Mahinda Rajapaksa appears to have emboldened a coalition of opponents.

item.title: Brazilians Return to Streets to Urge Rousseff’s Ouster
item.description: Though protests seemed to lack the urgency of earlier demonstrations, tens of thousands returned to the streets of cities across Brazil to express their displeasure with President Dilma Rousseff.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday.

item.title: Rivalry Is Renewed for Soccer Final in West Bank as Restrictions Are Eased
item.description: A soccer club from Gaza was allowed to enter the West Bank for the Palestine Cup final, the first time the competition between the best teams from Gaza and the West Bank had been played in 15 years.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and RAMI NAZZAL
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ittihad Shejaiya, a club from Gaza, and Ahli al-Khalil, from Hebron, West Bank, during a scoreless match on Aug. 6.

item.title: Iraqi Leader’s Overhaul Cuts 11 Cabinet Positions
item.description: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq reduced his cabinet to just 22 members as part of an overhaul in response to protests against corruption and poor governance.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ambiguity Shrouds the Case of a Missing Israeli of Ethiopian Descent
item.description: Almost a year after the disappearance of 29-year-old Avera Mengistu, his family remains mostly in the dark about his whereabouts or condition.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: After Delicate Negotiations, U.S. Says It Will Pull Patriot Missiles From Turkey
item.description: The decision came as the risk of Syrian Army missile attacks seemed to have eased and as concerns about Iran and North Korea demanded that the antimissile systems be made available for other missions.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A Patriot missile-defense system in Gaziantep, Turkey, on February 5, 2013.

item.title: Merkel Seeks to Head Off Opposition to Greek Bailout
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel said she expected the I.M.F. to participate in the new bailout as Germany’s Parliament prepared to vote on the package this week.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Ambiguity Shrouds the Case of a Missing Israeli of Ethiopian Descent
item.description: Almost a year after the disappearance of 29-year-old Avera Mengistu, his family remains mostly in the dark about his whereabouts or condition.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Obama Administration Warns Beijing About Covert Agents Operating in U.S.
item.description: American officials said that Beijing agents are pressuring Chinese citizens living abroad to return home as part of a campaign called Operation Fox Hunt.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, who met with President Obama last year, will be making a state visit to Washington next month.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Japan's Plutonium Problem
item.description: The country can't safely store its nuclear waste, so it should pay other states to take it.
item.dc:creator: PETER WYNN KIRBY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: India Finally Faces Up to an Ugly Reality
item.description: The India I live in today is more aware than ever before of the environmental horrors of its cities and towns.
item.dc:creator: AATISH TASEER

item.title: Government Airstrikes on Syrian Market Kill More Than 80
item.description: The death toll in Douma, a rebel-held territory, puts the incident among the deadliest air attacks during more than four years of conflict in Syria.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and MAHER SAMAAN
item.media:description: Victims injured by bombings were raced to local clinics on Sunday. The attacks struck a crowded market area in the city of Douma.

item.title: Provincial Minister in Pakistan Is Killed in Suicide Bombing
item.description: Shuja Khanzada, the home minister of Punjab Province, was killed along with at least 10 others in a bomb attack during a political meeting.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Hamid Gul, Pakistan’s Former Spy Chief, Dies at 78
item.description: Mr. Gul, a three-star general, was deeply involved in the country’s policy toward neighboring Afghanistan during the Soviet withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Hamid Gul, the former chief of Pakistan's spy agency, in Lahore, Pakistan, in 2012.

item.title: Amid Perilous Mediterranean Crossings, Migrants Find a Relatively Easy Path to Greece
item.description: Compared with other routes for refugees crossing the Mediterranean, the journey from Bodrum to Kos is remarkably organized and unfettered.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.media:credit: Daniel Etter for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Pakistani man prayed on a beach on the Greek island of Kos on Thursday after he crossed in an inflatable rubber boat from Bodrum, Turkey.

item.title: Tianjin Officials Struggle to Contain Fallout as Angry Relatives Demand Answers
item.description: A news conference in Tianjin was stormed by distraught relatives holding up lists of names, demanding information about dozens of missing firefighters.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Three days after the deadly blasts, the authorities have still been unable to identify the toxic chemicals smoldering at the site of the destroyed warehouse in Tianjin.
